messages.content:
> The mists creep low along the ground, curling like pale fingers around your boots as a chill wind whispers your name. Somewhere in the distance, a wolf howls—lonely, mournful, hungry. The sun is but a memory here, smothered by thick clouds that never part, and the land itself seems to brood under a sky that never smiles.

> You have been summoned—whether by fate, fortune, or cruel trickery—to the dread land of Barovia, a realm cloaked in sorrow and shadow. The people speak in hushed voices, their eyes wary, their homes ringed with garlic and superstition. They dare not speak too loudly of Castle Ravenloft, the looming fortress that watches from its crag like a vulture over a dying corpse.

> Within its ancient halls dwells Count Strahd von Zarovich, an immortal tyrant and vampire lord whose cold, calculating gaze has pierced the hearts of Barovians for centuries. His power is absolute, his appetite unending, and now... his attention has turned to you.

> Will you rise to become the hope of this cursed land, or will your blood join the countless others spilled in the mists of Ravenloft? Steel your hearts, sharpen your blades, and remember: In Barovia, not even the dead rest easy.
**Session 1: Whispers Before the Mist**

> The wind howls like a wounded beast beyond the timbered walls of the Hollow Hearth Inn.  Outside, the village of Briar Glen lies wrapped in fog. Not the natural mist of an autumn storm—but something denser, more purposeful. Lanternlight dies within it. Sound is swallowed whole. No traveler who entered this evening has dared leave again.

> Yet inside these tavern walls the food is hearty, and the ale is warm and frothy. A fire blazes in the hearth, and the tavern is alive with the tumbling voices of country folk. 

> You find yourselves in a dimly lit tavern, its wooden beams creaking softly overhead. The scent of ale and hearth smoke hangs in the air, the sound of muffled conversations, music, and the crackle of the fireplace. The tavern is cozy yet weathered, its walls adorned with faded tapestries and shelves cluttered with mementos of travelers long gone.

> The hearth casts a warm glow across the room, illuminating the faces of the patrons gathered around the tables. Some are lost in their own thoughts, nursing their drinks in silence, while others engage in lively conversation, their laughter filling the room with warmth.

> At the entrance of the tavern, just beneath the soft glow of lantern light, stands a long, sturdy table hewn from aged oak. It bears the scars of countless meals shared and tales told. A row of simple benches flank either side of the table. 

> Seated upon these benches are six figures, their silhouettes illuminated by the flickering torchlight.
@Curse of Strahd [PBP] (I would now like everyone to introduce their characters.)

`A large bugbear steps forward wearing a practical dark purple sleeveless tunic with gold trim and bindings, paired with dark pants and sturdy brown boots. Gold fabric wraps around his arms and waist like martial arts bindings. The outfit perfectly blends his monastic training with practical adventuring gear.`

`He speaks quietly, his dark eyes thoughtful:` "I'm Korrin Lefstryde. I know my appearance might be.... *concerning.* I was raised by druids and trained at a monastery. I like to  investigate disturbances to the natural balance." 

`He glances around at the group, nods, and finished with,` "A pleasure to meet you."

author.name: hybridxer0
author.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content: *A grey skinned elf with dark brown eyes and some visible scars on the partially shaven side of his head of his head sits opposite the large bugbear.  He wears studded leather over travel worn and dusty clothes, but the armor seems well oiled in spite of multiple scratches and repairs.  He has his shield strapped on his bag at his feet, a book  and hand crossbow in holsters on one side of his belt, and a short sword with a slight forward curve on the opposite hip.  He has a lean muscular build and sits with good posture and holds eye contact briefly then continues scanning the room with his eyes.  He idly rubs the ring on his finger as he clears his throat.*

"Pleasure to meet you Korrin." *His voice is deeper than his frame and build would indicate and the er sounds come out as uh* "I am Arkath Grey and if my scars do not cause you concern, then nothing about your appearance concerns me." *a brief hint of a smile on his usual serious expression* "I also investigate disturbances to what you refer to as the natural balance.  The Raven Queen does not care for such things as well."

`The figure seated at the table corner closest to the hearth does not immediately speak. Tall and wiry, he is cloaked in shadow and wrapped in tattered cloak, midriff exposing his brownish-charcoal skin. A white, marble mask conceals his face—its expression mournful and unchanging, horns sprouting form the top. His viol rests in his lap, charcoal-black and silver-strung, held with reverent care. His tail coils beside one leg of the bench, the pointed tip tapping a faint rhythm against the wood. With a final pluck of his viol’s string, he lifts his head. The red-outlined, black lenses of his mask catch the firelight as he scans the room, but reveal nothing.`

"I am called Aurexx."

`His voice is soft, deliberate, almost melodic—like a song played slowly in reverse.`

"I lend my voice to those who linger... and remember the ones the world has chosen to forget. I do not summon the dead...

They come to listen when I play."

`A brief pause, as if weighing whether more is necessary.`

"I followed a voice not my own... a hymn unfinished. It led me here, to this village swallowed by mist. Why? I do not know..."

`Then he falls silent once more, his gloved fingers resting gently against the strings.`

`Nico, a slender half-elf nursing a mead standing at the bar, hearing the familiar voice of Arkath introduce himself to Korrin, turns and walks over to join the group. His grey eye has an almost luminous quality in the tavern light.`

"Ah, Arkath good to see you, I was wondering what your message to meet was about, who are your new friends?"

`Korrin's amber eyes move thoughtfully between his new companions, taking in details with the careful observation of someone trained in both monastic discipline and natural awareness. His large frame shifts slightly forward as he speaks, voice remaining soft but carrying genuine interest.`

"Arkath .... Grey", `he says, seeming to try study the name with a cocked head,` "—a fitting name for one who serves the Raven Queen. Your scars speak of experience, and I've read often of those who've faced genuine hardship; they often see truth more clearly than others." `He nods respectfully.` "The natural balance I speak of includes the cycles of life and death. Perhaps our purposes align more than they initially appear."

`His gaze turns to the masked figure, and something in his posture suggests both curiosity and a deep, instinctive respect.` "Aurexx... there's something profound about music that calls to the forgotten. In my studies, I've found that plants respond to certain melodies—they remember seasons past in ways we barely understand." `He pauses, tilting his head slightly.` "An unfinished hymn led you here?" `His expression darkens, as his brow furrows. His eyes go distant for a second and he murmers,` "The mist that swallows villages rarely does so without reason."

`Korrin's attention shifts to the approaching half-elf, his keen eyes noting the luminous quality of Nico's grey eye with the same careful observation he might give to an unusual flower or cloud formation. He inclines his head politely.`

"It seems you and Arkath here have worked together before? `His gaze briefly flicks to Aurexx, then back to Nico.` "I confess I'm intrigued to learn what message brought you here. Coincidences like this..." `he trails off thoughtfully, absently noting how the tavern's sparse plant life seems slightly more vibrant in their immediate corner.` "What drew you to answer Arkath's call, if you don't mind my asking?"

author.name: hybridxer0
author.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content: *Pulling his attention away from Aurexx, Arkath glances Nico’s way* “As you know, my studies focus on supernatural occurrences.  The well placed bribe keeps many on the lookout for certain patterns. Disappearances.  Sightings of things strange and macabre.  Abhorrent or divine artifacts surfacing. When I received word that such goings on had transpired here, I reached out to our associates about getting some help. Oh, and I reached to you because I think you still owe me a few ales. *slight smile that disappears quickly before glancing around the room and settling once again on Aurexx* “That is an interesting instrument.    I would very much like to hear its story.”

*The smallest figure at the table, barely 2’10” but radiating quiet confidence, shifts forward. Trinkets and feathers woven into her brown braids catch the firelight, and her green eyes assess each speaker with practiced awareness.*

*Despite her size, the short sword at her hip and bow across her back suggest she’s no stranger to danger.
She touches a charm in her hair before speaking, her voice warm but carrying authority.*

“I’m Aria.” *She nods toward the others.* “Interesting company tonight.” *Her fingers twist in her hair and then tap once against the table.* “Something tells me this gathering isn’t as random as it appears.”

`Korrin is startled, flinching only slightly, as he had not noticed her due to her stature. He nods respectfully to Aria, his eyes taking note of her confident bearing despite her small stature.`

"Well met, Aria. You're right—this doesn't feel..... *random.*" `He glances around the table at the assembled group.` "Five different paths, all leading to the same mist-covered village. That suggests... ***purpose...***" `He seemed to muse on this for a bit, then leans forward slightly,` "What brought you here? I suspect your story might help us understand why we've all arrived at the same time."

author.name: hybridxer0
author.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content:
`Nico noticing his mug almost empty looks around the table and announces`
"You two are correct, there must be a reason we are all here..." 
`Looks at Aria, Aurexx, & Korrin `
"I have a feeling we are waiting for another, while we wait I owe Arkath a drink or two, how about you Aurexx, Aria & Korrin? I hear this tavern has a concoction called Ubmub... It has hints of Banana."

`The tavern door * groans * open just as Nico mentions the name of the tavern’s infamous banana brew. A tall figure fills the frame—broad-shouldered, road-worn, and carrying a presence that pulls attention whether he wants it or not.`

`His armor is a patchwork of hardened leather and half plate, beaten and scored from years of use. The mix of greens, browns, and grays blends well with forest or battlefield alike—though now it’s dusted with road grit and mist. A halberd rests slung across his back, and a greatsword hangs at his side with a large sigil that dangles from its hilt. His dark brown hair is damp from the fog, and his brown eyes flick from face to face with a slow, deliberate calm.`

`He stops just inside the threshold, sizing up the group and the room in equal measure.`

"Did I hear someone say they’re buying?"
`He steps forward, one brow arched and a crooked half-smile forming.`
"Because if there’s beer on the table, I’ve already found my purpose."

`He gives a brief nod to Nico, then Arkath, then the rest of the gathered strangers. Not unfriendly, but watchful—like a man who’s learned to take his time trusting.`

`His hand rests lightly on the pommel of his sword—not a threat, just habit.`
`Then he sets his pack beside a chair and eases into it with a faint grunt.`

"Name’s Ber. I’m here because too many folk have gone quiet in places that should never go still. Something's off in the air, and the mist outside stinks of it."

> Each of you came to Briar Glen for your own reasons. Yet none of you arrived without sensing it—a shift in the air, a weight in your chest, a silence where once there was harmony. The village seemed to call, though none of you received a formal summons until tonight.

- Korrin, the seeker of natural balance, felt the forests recoiling—not from blight, but from something watching.

- Arkath, the hunter of mysteries, was drawn by patterns: disappearances, ritual signs, and unmarked graves.

- Aurexx, led by a half-remembered hymn and a voice not his own, followed a song unfinished.

- Nico, haunted by whispers in the glass, noticed that the mists had begun to mirror his own movements. One village vanished. Then another. All without a sound.

- Arialyn, stalwart and unshaken, was pulled here by dreams of shadowed halls and the feeling that her order’s vows would be tested before long.

- Ber, the sword of judgment, followed silence—the kind that follows screams. Villages dead quiet. No signs of struggle. Just... nothing.

> Suddenly, the tavern door swings open, and a hush falls over the room. Framed by the lamp-lit fog, a form strides through the doorway. His heavy, booted footfalls and the jingle of his coins shatter the silence.

> In an accented voice he says, 

“I have been sent to you to deliver this message. If you are creatures of honor, you will come to my Master’s aid at first light. It is not advisable to travel the Svalich Woods at night!” 

> His brightly colored clothes are draped in loose folds about him, and his hat hangs askew, hiding his eyes in shadows. He stands proudly in a wide stance with folded arms. He pulls from his tunic a sealed letter, addressed to all of you in a beautiful flowing script. He drops the letter on the table.

“Take the west road from here some five hours march down through the Svalich Woods. There you will find my master in Barovia.”

> Amid the silent stares of the patronage, the man strides to the bar and says to the wary barkeep, 

“Fill the glasses, one and all. Their throats are obviously parched.” 

> He drops a purse heavy with gold on the bar.

`Ber watches the stranger approach, eyes narrowing beneath his furrowed brow. He doesn’t reach for a weapon—but one hand casually drifts toward the hilt of his greatsword, resting there like someone checking the weight of a familiar thought.`

`When the letter hits the table, Ber doesn’t pick it up. Instead, he leans back slightly in his chair, eye twitching just once.`

"First light, huh? That’s generous. Usually these kinds of invitations come after the screaming starts."

`His tone is dry, voice gravel-edged and calm.`
`He glances around at the others, lifts his mug in a half-toast.`

"Here’s to waking up early and marching into haunted woods for a man who won’t even show his face."

`Then, quieter, almost to himself:`
*Still better than sitting around pretending the quiet out there means peace.*

`He takes a sip, then nods toward the letter without looking at it.`

"Someone want to read that thing out loud before I start sharpening steel for a polite breakfast visit?"

`At Korrin’s words—"The mist that swallows villages rarely does so without reason"—the gentle tapping of Aurexx’s tail pauses. Stillness stretches for a breath, as if the thought hangs in the air too heavily to ignore.`
`Then, softly, the rhythm resumes.`

`He turns his veiled gaze to Arkath as if to answer... but his answer is interrupted by the man with jingling coin that entered the tavern. Aurexx’s head does not turn towards this man, but instead returns to the viol in his lap, fingers tracing the edge of a silver string, not even looking up towards the letter that was dropped onto the table.`

`At the banging of the door from the stranger's entrance Arkath slides his hands toward his shield and crossbow.`
(Does the mention of Barovia mean anything to Arkath.  May Arkath make a check to know if the stranger's appearance/behavior give any indication that they are Fey or Fiend?)
(Does Arkath recognize the seal on the letter?)

`Nico unsure of what is happening does a half-toast back to Ber, looking slowly from the bag of gold, to Arrigal, to the rest of the party, and focuses on the handwriting on the envelope and the seal.`
@Tinockerjoe **Arkath make an Arcana or Religion check for Barovia knowledge, and either Arcana or Insight for determining Arrigal’s nature. **
> Nico as you look at the letter, you see the wax bears the image of a raven clutching a sword, a symbol unfamiliar in formal heraldry—but evocative.
(Would either of those qualify for my Hunter’s Bane class feature?)
(I'd like to know if Korrin knows more about the sigil in question, if he's come across in his books)

author.name: hybridxer0
author.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content: (I rolled in DND beyond. That was a 19 for History of Barovia and a 19 forArcana on Arrigal. I rolled with advantage for the Arcana, but the first of the two rolls was the 19 just in case I wasn’t supposed to roll with advantage.)

`Eyes focused on Arrigal`
“Would you mind reading that Nico?”

`Korrin leans forward, studying the wax closely. He’s not a scholar of noble houses, but as a druid he’s learned what ravens mean in the wild.`

 “Ravens,” `he says,` “in every forest I’ve walked, they’re omens of death’s passage or the coming of winter—sometimes tied to the Raven Queen herself. But a raven clutching a sword?? I’ve never seen that exact motif in any druidic text or tribal glyph. If it’s not a personal crest of some local lord, it might well be a nod to death’s hand in war—something even a forest-dweller could sense. I don’t recall any official order using that seal, so I’d treat it like a warning: whoever sent this isn’t playing at hospitality.” 

`His look of concern almost instantly changes when he becomes distracted by the smell of bananas, his interest and attention now focused on sampling this... *Ubmub*`

messages.content:
@Tinockerjoe  **– Arcana (Arkath): 19 - Arrigal**

> You study the stranger. His colors, his cadence, the way he moved—it’s all too precise, too practiced. He doesn’t feel like a simple traveler. You detect no trace of fiendish or fey magic on him, yet his presence felt... thin—like he could vanish into mist at any moment. Whatever Arrigal is, he’s no illusion.
(Before reaching for the letter to read, I'd like to do an Arcana check on the envelope itself)
@AC **Nico, make an Arcana check on the envelope**

embeds.title: Nico Varn makes an Arcana check!
Korrin Lefstryde makes an Arcana check!

messages.content:
@AC  – **Arcana (Nico Varn): 21 - Envelope**

> As your fingers brush the edges of the envelope, you feel something… off. The parchment is thick, hand-made, but the ink shimmers faintly—not with light, but with absence. Like something is layered beneath the surface, hidden from the eye but not from the soul.

> Your trained senses pick up old magic, possibly binding magic, woven into the letter. Not a trap, but a seal—an arcane lock designed to ensure only the intended readers break it. Something about the energy suggests the message cannot be intercepted. It wants you to open it. It knows your name.

> The wax bears no enchantment, but it too resists scrutiny. As if it recognizes your touch, and dares you to look deeper. When you blink, the raven’s wings seem briefly extended—like shadow play on stone.

> Whatever power lingers in this message isn’t inherently hostile. But it is watching.
> And it has already chosen you.

@THE  H Y B R I D™**  – Arcana (Korrin): 11 - Sigil**

> Your eye for natural lore and symbolic language serves you well when reading the world, but this seal eludes you. The raven feels familiar—like an omen you’ve seen before the coming of winter wolves or forest fires. Yet here it feels... colder.

> You sense no magic from the wax. No enchantment, no trick. But the feeling it gives you—that’s the warning. The kind no spell can create.
> This is not a crest of heraldry. It’s a claim.

mentions.name: hybridxer0
mentions.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content:
*I feel like I should have heard of the Barovia, but in all my studies this name eludes me.  I think I would have noticed a town or manor along the west road. And why do I feel like this figure knows us without introduction.*
“Does it seem safe Nico?  I would hate to travel 5 hours into the Svalich only to be ambushed.”
`Arkath goes to sip his ale, but he chokes and sputters at the unexpected taste of Ubmub. Trying to compose himself`
“Enough with the suspense Nico, what does it say?”

"I wouldn't say this letter is *dangerous* but there is something *lingering*. " 
`Nico takes a shot of Ubmub` 
"Unless there is an objection, I guess I can take a gander at this...."

`After taking a huge gulp of the delicious beverage, suprised by it's allure, Korrin turns to Nico and says,` "I don't see any magic, but that raven… I’ve seen them overhead before a harsh winter or when a fire seized the woods. Here, it feels colder—like a warning."

`After pausing in thought, he continues,` " I don’t know any noble house that bears this mark. Doesn’t read like a crest, more like someone staking a claim. Trust your gut, Nico: whoever sent this wants something, and they’re not hiding behind fancy titles.”

author.name: hybridxer0
author.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content:
> As Nico breaks the wax seal, the table falls quiet.

> The parchment inside is crisp, edged with elegant red filigree, and the handwriting is smooth, flowing, and cold. The ink is deep black.

> Nico reads aloud:

> Hail thee of might and valor:
> 
> I, the Burgomaster of Barovia, send you honor—with despair.
> 
> My adopted daughter, the fair Ireena Kolyana, has been these past nights bitten by a vampyr. For over four hundred years, this creature has drained the life blood of my people. Now, my dear Ireena languishes and dies from an unholy wound caused by this vile beast. He has become too powerful to conquer.
> 
> So I say to you, give us up for dead and encircle this land with the symbols of good. Let holy men call upon their power that the devil may be contained within the walls of weeping Barovia. Leave our sorrows to our graves, and save the world from this evil fate of ours.
> 
> There is much wealth entrapped in this community. Return for your reward after we are all departed for a better life.
> 
> Kolyan Indirovich
> Burgomaster

`Nico takes another shot after finishing the letter...`
`Speaks to something not in the party`
"Well, I can die or get rich, win/win."
`Looking around`
""Oh you dont hear the voices..? 'd say lets take this. I'd vote lets take this hike..."

`At the mention of the word Vampyr Arkath’s face darkens and his attention shifts to the letter. As Nico finishes reading Arkath stands.`
“I’m already packed and I’d prefer to leave tonight, but” `Shouldering his pack` “I’m not fool hardy enough to go alone. If we’re setting out tomorrow I’d like to leave at first light.  Innkeeper, how much for a room?”
(Hearing about what’s happening to Ireena, does that sound like typical vampire behavior?)
`No matter the Innkeeper’s answer, Arkath will look to the others for their response`

> Arkath. as your thoughts turn toward the word vampyr, something cold and instinctual coils in your gut. You've studied blood curses, shadow rites, and creatures that blur the line between man and myth—but "vampyr" is not just another name for vampire.

> It’s older. Hungrier. Deliberate.

> Something about the letter’s words tugs at each of you.
﻿
- Korrin, the balance you seek shudders. No cycle—natural or spiritual—survives under a predator that feeds without end.
﻿
- Arkath, this vampyr… it's unlike anything you’ve studied. Its influence feels ancient and dangerously precise. The letter may be a plea—but it’s also a warning of an apex predator.
﻿
- Aurexx, the names taste familiar. Not from memory—but from music. Barovia, Ireena, Indirovich… fragments from that lost hymn. The spirits stir. Some whisper their names. Others simply weep.
﻿
- Nico, the mirror shard on your person grows colder. The ink in the letter… somehow resembles the ink of that other tome you found all those years ago. 
﻿
- Aria, you feel the weight of an oath not yet spoken. Something sacred is unraveling in that place. You don't know how—but you know your vows will be tested.
﻿
- Ber, the mention of "bitten by a vampyr" brings back battlefield tales you always dismissed as superstition. This time, it feels real. And if there’s a devil to be fought—you've already made your peace with the cost.

`As the letter is read aloud, Aurexx’s tail ceases its rhythm again.`
`But this time, it does not resume.`

`He doesn’t look up. He doesn’t move.`
`His masked face remains tilted toward the viol in his lap, fingers gently tracing the wood, not playing... simply listening.`

*Barovia. Ireena. Indirovich.*
*These names echo like dissonant chords in my ears...*

`Aurexx completely stops moving for a moment, even from breathing, as if listening to something, before resuming his usual delicate, soft movements.`

"I feel I have heard these names... though from what tune, I cannot recall..."
`His voice is no louder than before, but it cuts through the crackle of the hearth.`
"Perhaps they are threads in the song I am meant to find."

`He repositions his viol, ever gazing down towards it.`

"If Barovia mourns... then I must go where the threnody rings."

`Ber watches the brightly-dressed messenger stride off with the kind of confidence only a man with no intention of joining the fight can afford.`
`He exhales through his nose—something between a sigh and a quiet snort—and leans forward, resting heavy forearms on the scarred tavern table.`

"Right. At first light it is."
`He taps the table once with two fingers, then picks up his half-finished drink.`
"Better to face the woods with a bit of sleep and no regrets."

*Not that anyone sleeps well when the air feels like it’s holding its breath.*

`As he takes a sip, the letter's contents echo in his mind—especially one line.`

💭 *Bitten by a Vampyr…*

*That’s not a warning. That’s a confession. And it’s too damn calm.*

`Ber sets the mug down and glances around the table, his tone low.`
"Anyone else catch that line? Not attacked, not hunted... bitten. Like he let it happen to her.. Or like he didn’t get a choice."
`He shakes his head once.`
"Either way, that’s a bad way to start a letter. Hope the rest of the story’s better than the prologue."

`With a groan of old armor and tired joints, Ber rises from his seat. The battered plates of brown, green, and grey leather shift with him, bearing scars whispering their own stories of battle. He gives the group a nod.`
"Getting a room. If we’re marching at dawn, I want four walls, a door that locks, and something dry to sleep on."

`He crosses the tavern floor, boots thudding solidly on old boards, and approaches the barkeep.`

"Evening. Room for one, just for tonight. I don’t snore. Much."
*He sets a few coins down, then adds, almost as an afterthought:*
"And if anyone knocks past midnight, and they ain’t breathing right—just tell ’em I already paid my tithe to the dead this month."

> Ber, as you cross the tavern floor, the air seems to shift. Conversations hush—just slightly, just enough to notice—and all eyes flicker toward you and the bar.

> The barkeep, a bearded man with nervous eyes, forces a tense smile as you approach. But he doesn’t greet you. His gaze is fixed just past your shoulder.

> That’s when you hear the scrape of wood on wood—chairs shifting, boots stomping—and the raucous laughter of men who want to be heard.
﻿
> A burly thug with a scar splitting his upper lip reaches out and grabs the tankards the barkeep had just poured—your drinks. He turns toward you with a sneer, his gang close behind.

“Well, well... looks like grandpa needs to go to bed.”
﻿
>  He grins, gold tooth glinting in the firelight. Behind him, four more thugs lounge in chairs like wolves in tall grass, armed and half-drunk.
﻿
> Another snickers. 
﻿
“Came up here askin’ for a room, boys. Gonna tuck in early, old man? Want us to sing you a lullaby?”
﻿
> The lead thug raises his mug in a mocking toast. 
﻿
“You’re lucky we were here to catch your drinks before they got warm. That peacock messenger of yours paid up real nice. Real shame he forgot to mention they weren’t for us.”

> The others hoot and slap the bar.

> A wiry bandit with a broken nose chimes in, gesturing toward the rest of the party.

 “These your kids, old man? Cute. Real mismatched little orphan gang you’ve got there.”

> The barkeep winces but says nothing—his hands tremble under the bar as he slowly slides a small knife beneath the counter, just in case.

> The scarred thug leans closer, the ale in his mug sloshing onto Ber’s boot.

“Tell you what, grandpa. Why don’t you take your bones upstairs and sleep this one off? We’ll make sure that coin is well spent..."

> He reaches out and grabs the tankards the barkeep had just poured.

`At the loud sound of the chair scraping, Arkath would like to don his shield. When the thugs laugh and get rowdy, he will attempt to subtly tap one of his runes to cast Armor of Agathys and start stealthily moving towards an advantageous place in the bar to have a clear shot at the thug(s).  Preferably with cover`

*Looks like it won’t be a quiet evening after all*

“We might want to spread out” 

`He whispers to the others as he starts moving`
(Does Nico notice if these thugs have any sort of coin in their group or if they are speaking in thieves' cant?)

@AC **Nico, roll a Perception check to spot coin purses or signs of wealth among the thugs.**

**Roll an Insight check to determine if any of their gestures or phrasing hint at underworld slang or coded speech.**

embeds.title: Nico Varn makes a Perception check!
Nico Varn makes an Insight check!

messages.content:
@AC  **Perception (Nico Varn) : 10 - Spotting coin**

> Your eyes flick toward their belts, boots, and hands—searching for the telltale glint of coin. Unfortunately, between the shifting bodies, spilled ale, and dim firelight, most of what you catch are bulky shapes beneath rough cloaks and clinking sounds masked by tankards slamming and chairs scraping.

> You don’t spot a clear purse or pouch—no flash of gold or ornate clasp—but it’s clear they’ve got something rattling in their pockets. Whether that’s coin, dice, or bones is anyone’s guess.
‎

`Korrin’s ears twitch at Arkath’s whisper. He tightens the wrappings on his forearms and shifts his weight, low stance ready. With a slow breath that smells of pine and damp earth, he slips around in a wide circle around the tavern`

`He murmurs under his breath,` “And I was just enjoying myself..." 

`His eyes, dark and steady, track the scarred thug’s movements as he closes the distance, fingers brushing the old grimoire at his side—ready to call on the forest’s breath if blood spills. Korrin’s shoulders coil with silent tension, every muscle primed to spring.`

embeds.title: Nico Varn casts Prestidigitation!

fields.name: Description
fields.value:
You create a magical effect within range. Choose the effect from the options below. If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have up to three of its non-instantaneous effects active at a time.

**_Sensory Effect._** You create an instantaneous, harmless sensory effect, such as a shower of sparks, a puff of wind, faint musical notes, or an odd odor.

**_Fire Play._** You instantaneously light or snuff out a candle, a torch, or a small campfire.

**_Clean or Soil._** You instantaneously clean or soil an object no larger than 1 cubic foot.

**_Minor Sensation._** You chill, warm, or flavor up to 1 cubic foot of nonliving material for 1 hour.

**_Magic Mark._** You make a color, a small mark, or a symbol appear on an object or a surface for 1 hour.

**_Minor Creation._** You create a nonmagical trinket or an illusory image that can fit in your hand. It lasts until the end of your next turn. A trinket can deal no damage and has no monetary worth.

messages.content:
> The air thickens, the scent of sweat and spilled ale clinging to the tavern’s wooden bones. The tension is a string pulled taut—just waiting for someone to pluck it.

> Korrin shifts into motion—graceful, silent. A predator in monk’s robes.
> Arkath’s rune pulses as magical frost coats his shoulders, invisible but humming with promise.
> Aria slides from her seat like a shadow learning to stand upright.
> Nico, fingers twitching with arcane readiness, murmurs a minor incantation—

> A spray of sparks erupts from the opposite side of the tavern, casting dancing lights across the smoky rafters.

> The thugs flinch, a few looking up—one even ducks instinctively.

> Korrin, you see your chance.

`Korrin moves fast—too fast for a drunk to track.

One heartbeat he’s by the shutters. The next, he’s behind the lead thug.

No warning. Just a sharp, clean strike to the ribs.

Korrin doesn’t say a word. Just plants his feet, ready to hit again if the fool’s still standing.`

embeds.title: Korrin Lefstryde attacks with Surprise Attack!

messages.content:
> The lead thug doesn’t even have time to scoff.
﻿
*CRACK.*
﻿
> Korrin’s fist drives into his ribs with such precision and force that bones audibly shift. The thug staggers sideways, a strangled gasp escaping him as all the breath is slammed from his chest.
> ﻿
> He drops the tankard. The clang rings out like a bell tolling judgment.
﻿
> Behind the bar, the barkeep recoils. Across the room, chairs screech and boots shuffle—some in panic, others in preparation for violence.
﻿
> The thug stumbles, eyes wild. He opens his mouth to shout, but all that comes is a wheeze and a string of spit.
﻿
> His knees buckle. He doesn’t fall—but only just.
﻿
> Somewhere in the tavern, a bottle rolls off a table and shatters.
﻿
> The room is one heartbeat from chaos.

`Korrin exhales slowly, fist still lowered from the strike. He doesn’t press the attack. Instead, he plants his feet, eyes sweeping the room—not in fear, but in calculation.`

*By the Hells…* `he thinks,` *why do these situations always seem to find me?*

`He glances to Nico, then Arkath, Aurexx, and finally Ber, giving them the barest nod—as if to say: Your turn.`

author.name: hybridxer0
author.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content:
`Ber’s boots don’t move, even as the thug buckles. He watches the man wheeze, one hand braced on the bar, the other clutching his ribs.`

*Well, that shut him up.*
*Korrin didn’t ask permission. Didn’t need to. Still…*

`Ber glances sideways at the others—at Korrin, tense and ready; at Nico, sparks still fading in the air; at Arkath and Aria, poised and sharp-eyed. Then back to the bar.`

`He steps forward—calm, deliberate—and places a hand on the thug’s shoulder. Not hard. Just… enough.`

“You alright, friend?”
`He lifts his voice a little so the others can hear.`
“Man takes a gut-shot and don’t fall down? That’s toughness. That’s somethin’.”

`Ber gives him a little shake—firm, like a warning masked as encouragement. Then lets go.`

“Now listen.”
`His voice lowers again—measured, slow, just a touch of gravel.`
“We came in peace. That drink was already paid for, and I don’t much care who drinks it… as long as nobody bleeds in it.”

`He turns to the bar, picks up one of the spilled mugs, and sniffs it.`

“Though I was hopin’ this’d taste better’n bathwater.”
`He shrugs.`
“Must be an acquired taste.”

`Then back to the barkeep, loud enough for the room to hear:`

“How ‘bout that room key, friend? Unless the gentleman here needs it more’n I do.”

`Ber smiles. It’s wide. It’s not warm. But it’s… polite.`

> The tavern holds its breath—caught between the tension of a strike and the weight of Ber’s calm, anchored words.

> The lead thug, still hunched and pale, wheezes raggedly, one hand clutching his ribs, the other gripping the bar for balance. He looks from Korrin to Ber, then to the rest of the party—seeing weapons not yet drawn, but hands resting close, eyes sharp. A pack of wolves waiting to see if he’ll growl or limp away.

> Ber’s voice lands like a hammer wrapped in velvet. The tension doesn’t vanish—but it pauses.

> You can see it now in the room: the gang behind him shifting uneasily, not quite ready to jump in, not quite ready to back down. The barkeep dares to glance up, frozen between hope and fear.

(Let’s see where this goes with a Group Intimidation Check)

(I will take the total of the players Intimidations Checks contested to the total of the thugs Charisma Saving Throws to determine if the room de-escalates, or explodes into full combat.)

@Curse of Strahd [PBP] **Everyone roll an Intimidation check**

messages.content:
**Party Intimidation Total: 97**

**Enemy Charisma Save Total: 91**

> The crackle of tension lingers like the last echo of a thunderclap.

> Korrin stands rooted behind the lead thug, calm as a coiled storm. Arkath’s eyes gleam with frost, his hand never far from steel. Aurexx says nothing, but his silence watches. Nico flicks sparks from his fingertips—more than a parlor trick, less than a threat. And Ber... Ber smiles that too-polite smile that makes grown men rethink the last few minutes of their lives.

> Aria’s green eyes are steady. Her posture—light, nimble, yet unyielding—says she’s already calculated the shot.

> The thugs—cocky a minute ago—begin to lose their rhythm.

> One glances to the others, uncertain. Another shifts uneasily, his bravado unraveling beneath your collective gaze. Even the more hardened ones—the pirate with the silver tooth, the scarred thug now nursing bruised ribs—begin to reassess their place in this room.

> Then it happens.

> The biggest of them, the one who first mocked you, spits blood on the floor and straightens—but instead of barking another threat, he lifts both hands slightly.

“Wasn’t lookin’ for a brawl,” 

> he mutters, voice low and gravelly. 

“Just... caught up in the drink, y’know?”

> He backs up a step, then turns to his mates. 

“Let’s go. We’ll find friendlier floors elsewhere.”

> The rest begin to disperse—some slower than others, some muttering curses under their breath, but none foolish enough to linger. One bandit even tosses a tankard onto a table with a dull thud, as if to say we didn’t want it anyway.

> Moments later, the door swings wide, and the gang fades into the mist-soaked night.

> The tavern exhales as one. Patrons return to drinks. The barkeep—still pale—sets a room key gently on the bar and slides it toward Ber without a word.

> A fire pops in the hearth. Outside, the fog thickens.

> The night resumes—but you’ve made it yours.
`Aurexx not once rising from his seat or looking up, finally once again resumes the soft, rhythmic pattering of his tail.`

> Aurexx’s tail begins again.

> Soft. Subtle.
> A rhythmic tap-tap-tap against the tavern floor—like a second heartbeat no one noticed until now.

> Not a threat. Not a challenge.

> Just a reminder.

> The masked bard hasn’t moved. Hasn’t looked up. Hasn’t drawn steel or cast spell.

> But still…
> He is here.

> The barkeep exhales for the first time in minutes and slides a room key onto the bar with trembling fingers.

> His voice, when it comes, is quiet but full of genuine relief.

“…Thank you.”

“They’ve been… coming in for weeks now. Scaring off my regulars, breaking things, drinking on coin they didn’t earn. Guards won’t touch ’em. Say it’s not worth the trouble.” 

> He shakes his head, then meets Korrin’s gaze with a mix of awe and gratitude.

“You didn’t have to do what you did. Most folk just look the other way.”

> He gestures behind the bar, pulling free a ring of iron keys.

“Rooms are yours. No charge. Not tonight. Not after that.” 

> He sets them down gently. 

“Clean beds. Fresh water. And if you need breakfast before you head out in the morning…” 

> He chuckles, a little bitter, a little hopeful. 

“Well, I’ll make sure it’s hot.”

> He straightens up, clearing his throat and wiping his hands on a faded cloth. 

“Rest easy, if you can. You’ve earned it.”

> Behind him, the hearth burns just a little warmer.

`Aria walks to the bar, gracefully hops up on a stool and takes one of the keys`

“Thank you, my friend” 

`she hops off of the stool at the bar beginning to return to her place at the table`

“I think it may be yet a bit early to retire, they may return. I think I shall remain a bit longer in case any assistance is needed”

(Aria would like to check and see if there is any minor damage bruising or cuts on Korrin from his unarmed strike)

`Arkath sheathes his dagger and approaches the bar.  He picks up a key`

“With all of the commotion, perhaps it wouldn’t be a bad idea to set a watch?   I don’t mind staying up a bit.  If Aria doesn’t mind the company?  Otherwise, I can wait outside our rooms.  I’m a light sleeper”
`Arkath touches the ring on his finger and rotates it on his finger idly`
*The land sure seems restless and stifled tonight.  It feels like a weight is draped over everything*

`Nico picks up a key`

"Well that was some good entertainment, perhaps we all need quite the rest before the long walk in the morning...."
`Looking at the sack of gold`
"... Now what should we do with *that*..." 
`Motions towards the bag`

`Aria nods at Arkath respectfully`

“Always happy for the backup, and comradry with those who I’m meant to travel”

`she returns to her seat at the table, shot of umbub (which is more like a drinking glass to her) in hand, keenly watchin her surroundings and idly touching the charms in her hair occasionally`

`Arkath takes a seat facing the door.  He picks up the bag left for them.`
“Feels like it’s got a good bit of coin.”
`Arkath sets the bag in the middle of the table.  He reaches in a pouch by his side and pulls out a small knife. Keenly sharpened with runes carved into the handle and marked into the blade.  He begins shaving the sides of his head, eyes trained on the door and occasionally sweeping the room`
“I don’t know if we should trust that stranger, but it seems this will pay well. I pray the Raven Queen gives us a quiet evening from here on out.  What are your specialties Aria?  I myself am fond of studying and hunting the supernatural.”

`aria watches Arkath closely as she also keeps eye on their surroundings, ever ready for chaos to ensue. Her hand drifts to the charm in her hair, and upon Arkaths question quickly returns to her glass. She is quiet for a moment, and when she speaks, the tone is clear, decisive, and commanding for someone of such small stature `

“I am a fighter… and a healer.”

`Ber watches the door swing shut. He listens—to the silence, to the barkeep’s thanks, to the crackle of firewood finally audible again. Only then does he turn to his companions.`

`He picks up the key slowly, turning it in his hand like he’s weighing something heavier than iron.`

“No charge,” he said. That’s a first.
*Guess it’s good to be feared. Or liked. Or both.*

`He lets out a soft grunt—half amusement, half sigh—and gives the barkeep a respectful nod.`

“I’ll take the one near the stairs. Easier to stomp down if things get rowdy again.”

`He tucks the key into his belt and turns toward the table where his companions regroup.`

“Good work, Korrin.”
`His voice is quiet, but firm enough to carry.`
“Fast hands, steady head. You knocked the wind outta him and still gave me room to speak. That’s discipline. That’s rare.”

`He pauses. His eyes scan the others—Arkath, Aria, Nico, Aurexx—each in their own rhythm, each still half-wired for more trouble.`

“And the rest of you—thanks for lettin’ me try talkin’ first.”
`He chuckles, just a little.`
“Hard to believe I used to lead with the other option.”

`Ber walks toward the bag of gold left behind. He squints at it like it might still bite.`

“As for this—” `he taps the side of the bag with a knuckle,` “—we’ll deal with it tomorrow? After we’ve had sleep, and soup, and maybe... a prayer or two. Or, give it to the keep, I don't really care for luxury anyways”

`Finally, to the barkeep:`

“If they do come back, knock on the ceiling. I don’t sleep through trouble.”

`He steps back, rolls his shoulders, and adds over his shoulder—`

“...But I do snore. So maybe wait 'til morning unless it’s real urgent.”

`Ber pauses midway up the stairs, boots creaking on the wood as Aria’s words echo through the tavern:`

“I am a fighter… and a healer.”

`He glances over his shoulder—not fully turning, just enough for the firelight to catch the edge of his weathered face.`

“Glad you’re on our side.”

`Ber gives a small nod and continues to his room.`

`Aria returns Ber’s nod, a small almost unnoticeable smile appearing on her face as her hand return to her charm. She takes a small sip of her drink and turns to Nico`

“This drink really does have hints of banana. It’s reminds me of home. It is quite excellent.”

> As Ber disappears up the stairs, the tavern finally settles into something like calm.

> Korrin’s hand still bears the faint red flush of the strike. As Aria moves closer, the soft clink of her armor the only sound, she reaches out and examines his hand with practiced care. There is no injury to be found but might be a little stiff by morning.

> Behind the bar, the barkeep finishes mopping up the last of the spilled ale. He looks over at your group again, gratitude still heavy in his eyes.

“If I may,” 

> he says, voice low and honest,

 “what you did tonight… that’ll give some of the folk in this town their courage back. Maybe even enough to stay.”

> He nods once more.

“Sleep as long as you like. I’ll have breakfast ready at sunrise. Gods willing, there’ll be no more trouble before then.”

> As the remaining patrons quietly return to their drinks and conversations, subdued but no longer fearful, the night stretches on. The fire dims. Boots rest. Words soften.

> Above the rafters, the wind sighs through the eaves like a lullaby.

> Barovia waits. But not tonight.

> Tonight, you rest.

`Nico looks to Aria`
"I'm glad another is reminded of home by this concoction"
`Nico acknowledging Aria's appreciation for the Ubmub turns to the bartender and asks for 5 bottles of Ubmub for the journey ahead`

`Korrin rolls his shoulders, feeling the coiled tension from the confrontation slowly unwind. The adrenaline that kept him sharp and ready is fading, leaving behind the familiar ache of muscles held too tightly for too long.

He approaches the bar and gestures quietly to the barkeep, who pours another pint of the banana-flavored Ubmub without question. The sweet, tropical scent rises from the mug as Korrin wraps his large hands around it, savoring the aroma.

Without a word, he moves to the table and settles onto the bench beside Aria. His presence is calm but alert—not the hair-trigger readiness of moments before, but the steady watchfulness of someone who's learned that trouble rarely announces itself twice in one night.

He takes a slow sip of the Ubmub, amber eyes scanning the now-peaceful tavern over the rim of his mug. The firelight catches the gold trim of his purple tunic, and for the first time since the letter arrived, his breathing is deep and even.

Sitting beside the small but formidable halfling, he radiates a quiet contentment—grateful for competent allies, good drink, and the simple pleasure of a crisis well-handled.`

author.name: hybridxer0
author.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content:
> The barkeep, who’d just finished stacking the last broken chair in the corner, turns at Nico’s request. His tired eyes brighten a touch—not with mirth, but with a quiet, grateful resolve. He steps behind the bar and disappears momentarily through a worn door into the back.

> There’s the soft clatter of glass, the pop of a cork being tested, and the muffled sound of something heavy being shifted aside. Moments later, he returns with a crate, half-covered in a faded burlap cloth. Nestled within are five stout bottles—each hand-corked and sealed with wax the color of golden bananas, faintly sticky to the touch.

"Best I’ve got," 

> he says, setting the crate gently on the bar. 

"A few of these came from an old brewer down south—called it a 'jungle brew.' Said the recipe came to him in a dream. I never asked which kind."

> He gives a small chuckle, then sobers.

"Take them with my thanks. If what that letter says is true… you'll need something strong to carry with you. Might not keep you safe, but it'll make the road feel a little warmer."

> He pauses, then adds softly, 

"And if you find yourselves back this way... tell me how it ends."

> With that, he steps back, leaving the crate for Nico to gather, and returns to wiping down the already clean counter—his way of keeping busy, perhaps, while the weight of the coming morning settles in.

`sitting in the silence for a while, Aria eyes Nico’s gift with interest and then slightly chuckles to herself`

“That there would be a years worth  back home.”

`she then turns to Korrin`

“You mind is clear, but your body seems weary, friend. Rest well this evening, I feel we may need it.”

`with that statement, Aria finishes her drink, and bids her companions good evening to retire to her room`

> After Aria’s words settle like a final note in a fading song, the warmth of the hearth becomes the only voice left speaking in the common room. Outside, the mist presses against the windows, ever-watching, ever-patient—but it does not breach the threshold.

> The inn settles.

> One by one, keys turn in locks, boots are unlaced, weapons laid within arm’s reach. Somewhere down the hall, the groan of old wood echoes as a traveler shifts in sleep. 

> And then... morning.

> It comes slowly—uncertain, dim. The sun does not pierce the gray that hangs heavy outside, but light seeps in, diffused and colorless. The hearth is cold. The mist remains, thicker now, wreathing the edges of Briar Glen like a hand reluctant to release its grip.

> But the smell of fresh bread and crisp air wafts faintly from below. The barkeep, true to his word, has prepared a modest breakfast—warm porridge, coarse bread, salted meats, and a pot of bitterblack tea.

`Ber descends the stairs with slow, deliberate steps, the creak of old wood beneath his boots syncing with the rhythmic clink of armor straps being adjusted. His half-plate has been hastily cleaned, though a few bloodstains linger like memories. His expression is rested, but watchful.`

`He pauses at the bottom of the stairs, scanning the tavern until his gaze settles on his companions.`
“Smells like the gods themselves are cookin’,” he mutters, then adds with a smirk, “and by Torm, I could eat a horse.”

`Crossing the room, Ber nods once to the barkeep, then takes a seat near the fireless hearth, eyeing the breakfast with honest appreciation. He tears a hunk of bread free and dips it into the porridge`

“Rest did me good. But I’ve got the feeling we’ll earn our keep today."

*That fog’s too quiet.*

`Nico wakes up unsure of the bed he was in. They all blur together night after night on the move. Descending the stairs silently. Takes a seat a seat at the table with Ber.`

"I slept like a baby... and I've never met a baby who's slept good... How's that porridge Ber? This mist gives me the heebie jeebies."

`Nico thanks the Inn keeper again for the case of Ubmub.`

`Arkath descends the stairs nimbly, almost seeming to glide.  He glances around, grabs a bit of everything offered, and sits facing the door.  He cups the hot tea in his mug and breathes in its aroma`
*This warmth still doesn’t seem to chase away the cold of this oppressive fog*
“My trance was restful, but these Mists trouble me.  I’ll feel better once we get some road beneath our feet.  That was pretty impressive last night, Ber.  I’m glad you have such a cool head.”

`Ber doesn’t look up from his bowl at first—he gives the porridge a thoughtful stir, then lifts a spoonful slowly to his mouth.`
`He chews once. Swallows.`
`Then, glancing up at Nico with that familiar half-smirk:`

“Tastes like wet oats and a bad memory.”
`He pushes the bowl an inch away.`
“Which makes it the best breakfast I’ve had in days.”

`When Arkath offers their praise, Ber meets his gaze with quiet gratitude. He nods once, firmly.`

“Thank you. Wasn’t sure if we’d end the night in a warm bed or a cold brawl. But when Korrin hit that bastard in the ribs…”
`He chuckles—just once.`
“…I figured the choice had already been made. All that was left was how much blood we wanted on the floor.”

`Ber leans back in his chair, arms folding across his chest.`
“But I’ll take peace when I can get it. Even in Barovia.”

`The tap of tail against wood heralds Aurexx long before his boots touch the tavern floor. Each step down the stairs is placed with careful, soft, yet deliberate rhythm, like a metronome keeping the tail-tapping in time.`

`When he reaches his table, the pitter-patter stops, and he sits. The marble mask reflecting the low morning light; its mournful expression unchanged. He sits, without word, and waits, viol in his lap, and its bow on his back.`

`Korrin descends the stairs quietly, his movements still carrying that fluid grace despite the slight stiffness in his striking hand. The scent of breakfast mingles with the ever-present mist seeping through the tavern's walls—an unsettling combination that speaks to the unnatural nature of their destination.`

`He nods respectfully to his companions already gathered, then approaches the spread. Taking modest portions of bread and porridge, he pauses at the sight of the cases of Ubmub set aside from the night before.`

`A rare, genuine smile crosses his features as looks around.` "The barkeep remembered," `he murmurs, thinking fondly of the banana-flavored beverage. He decides, however, to pour himself a small cup of the bitterblack tea to pair with the porridge, bread, and meats.`

`Settling at the table, he glances toward the mist-shrouded windows.` "The fog feels... wrong. Not like any natural weather pattern I've studied." `His dark eyes meet each of his companions in turn.` "But, hey, at least we face it with full bellies and clear heads..." `turning to look at Nico, he continues,` *"...assuming the voices are quieter this morning, Nico?"*

`He raises his cup slightly — not quite in a toasting manner, but an acknowledgment of the strange comfort found in small pleasures before dark journeys.`

author.name: hybridxer0
author.nickname: THE  H Y B R I D™

messages.content:
`Aria descends from the staircase swift and quietly to the table where her companions sit. She notices a few almost imperceptible jumps as she graceful appears on her chair, noticing her companions may not have heard her arrival. She inwardly smiles, for someone who isn’t a rogue, she is small and light enough to go under the radar quite easily. And it always seems to make both foe and friend underestimate her. While this has no sense of baring on her ego, she occasionally finds it humorous that others are surprised by her presence.`

“Good morning”

 `she says as she helps herself to the breakfast laid in front of them`

“This fog is… unsettling.”

`her hand idly moves to her hair charm, and she is quiet a moment, not giving any hint to her thoughts and meditations`

> The barkeep, eyes lined with sleepless worry and a rough towel slung over one shoulder, glances over as each of you filter down from your rooms. His expression softens—just slightly—at the sight of your full table and shared silence.

> He sets down a pot of hot tea and nods in greeting, voice low but steady.

"You’ve got strong hearts, all of you. Haven’t had a quiet night here in weeks, not 'til last."

> He glances toward the window, where the mist clings stubbornly to the glass like breath on a tombstone.

"Storms’ll come and hopefully clear that fog."

> As the last spoon clinks against a bowl and boots scrape softly against the worn tavern floor, a hush falls once more over the Morning Hearth. The barkeep, standing behind the counter with wrung hands and a lingering look of quiet gratitude, watches you prepare.

> He doesn’t speak—doesn’t need to. His nod says enough: Thank you. And gods watch over you.

> You push open the tavern door, and the world outside greets you not with sunlight, but with a wall of white.

> The fog has thickened overnight, pressing low and heavy across the village like a mourner’s shroud. The air is biting cold, breath visible with each exhale. Tiny flakes drift down like ash from a dying fire, catching in hair, fur, and cloak.

> The road west—narrow and crooked—disappears into a sea of pale mist. No wind. No sound. Just the soft crunch of frost beneath your boots and the occasional creak of your gear.

> Behind you, the village of Briar Glen holds its breath. Before you, the Svalich Woods await—gnarled trees like skeletal fingers reaching from the veil.

> A raven calls from somewhere unseen.

> The mists begin to close behind you.

`Korrin pauses at the threshold, his amber eyes scanning the unnatural wall of mist. The raven's call draws his attention—not the harsh caw of alarm, but something more deliberate. Ominous.`

`He breathes in, then sighs deeply, centering himself as his monastic training demands, while his druidic senses recoil from the wrongness pressing against the natural world. This fog doesn't move with wind or weather—it *waits*.`

`Keeping his voice low: ` "We should probably stay close. This mist doesn't look natural—almost as if it's being held here."  ***`(I'd like to do a nature check)`*** `His bugbear heritage sharpens his awareness as he peers into the white void. He finishes with,` "If we get separated...", `then shudders.`

`He glances back at his companions, hand brushing the grimoire at his side.` "That raven's call—it's not warning us away. It's calling us forward. Into whatever's waiting in those woods."

`Without another word, he steps into the mist alongside his companions, every sense alert.`

messages.content:
@Tinockerjoe **Perception (Arkath Grey): 21 – Scanning the Mists**

> The mists swirl unnaturally thick, yet Arkath’s trained eyes cut through the haze better than most. Shapes loom and dissolve beyond the tree line—twisted roots, gnarled branches like reaching hands—but nothing moves of its own will. 

> But something is watching.

> Not from ahead. Behind.
> A flicker—just once—like a shadow turning in on itself.

> You glance over your shoulder.

> A raven.

> Not the same as before. This one is perched high on a frost-bitten limb above the road, its feathers fluffed against the cold. It doesn’t caw. It only watches—head cocked, beady eyes reflecting no light. Then, without a sound, it turns and vanishes into the fog.

@THE  H Y B R I D™ **Nature (Korrin Lefstryde): 23 – The Truth of the Mist**

> Korrin stops, brow furrowing as he crouches low and presses his palm against the cold, damp earth.

> The trees whisper—but not with wind. The moss seems wrong—damp, but not from dew. And the mist… the mist isn’t rolling in. It’s stationary, like a curtain hung by invisible hands.

> You’ve walked through dozens of forests, studied the breath of a hundred biomes—but this… this is manipulated nature. The air is stale, unnaturally humid, yet carries no true scent of decay or life. Something—someone—is controlling the very climate here.

> More than that... you feel it. The mists are not fully alive, no, but aware. Like an extension of will, or a boundary spell cast too wide and old to be seen plainly. You're not simply entering fog. You're being allowed in.

messages.content:
*Yes, it is good to have allies in this*
“Usually I would take the sight of a raven as a good omen or a comfort, but not today.  Not in these mists.”

@AC **Investigation (Nico Varn): 14 – Peering Into the Mists**

> Nico scans the edge of the mists, narrowing his eyes. His breath hangs on the air like a ghost as he steps lightly, gaze searching for shape, for hint, for pattern.

> The trees are wrong—growing at slightly off angles, as if repelled by something unseen in the air. No animal tracks. No fresh droppings. Not even spiderwebs. Just the soft hiss of wind that never quite touches your skin.

> Then he spots it.

> About fifteen feet into the mist, low to the ground—a bootprint.

> Humanoid. Heavy. Facing *toward* the road into the woods. Not made by any of your group.

> But there’s only *one.*

> The mist around it remains undisturbed.

> Almost as if... whatever made it vanished mid-step.
(Would aria have any insight or knowledge of these mists from her life as a halfling and experiences form the past?)
@Mis **Aria make a History Check - Recall teachings of mists**

embeds.title: Arialyn makes a History check!

messages.content: (I will use my luck ability to reroll)

embeds.title: Arialyn makes a History check!

messages.content:
@Mis **History (Arialyn): 3 – Recall teachings of mists**

> Aria frowns slightly as her fingers brush the charm in her hair. She sifts through half-remembered stories—old hearthside warnings, tales whispered by traveling elders, even a few solemn teachings from her order.

> But this mist... it defies every frame of reference. It’s not the coastal fogs that roll over hills, nor the mountain mists of her homeland. There’s no familiar cadence in it—no scent, no weight of water, no warmth.

> Whatever memory she tries to summon slips through her thoughts like smoke through fingers.

`Nico looking to the group`
"There's something ahead... Lets tread carefully... *This* road, makes me uneasy."

`Ber says nothing.`

`He stands just behind the others, a pillar of silence amid the nervous chatter and quiet deductions.`
`The mist presses in like a second sky, low and heavy, but it finds no purchase on him.`
`Where others peer forward, Ber holds the rear. Where voices fill the space with questions and theories, he offers only breath and steel.`

`His eyes sweep the treeline. Not searching—watching. There is a difference.`

`The cold bites, but it does not chill him.`
`The silence lingers, but it does not unsettle him.`

`He listens as Korrin speaks of unnatural weather. Watches Arkath count heads like a commander. Hears Nico murmur about lost footsteps in the snow.`

`But Ber… waits.`

`When the raven lands and stares—he stares back.`
`When the wind dies, and the trees seem to lean inward—he plants his feet.`

`Let the others call out what they see. Ber is here for what cannot be seen.`
`The moment when something *dares* to reveal itself.`

`He is a mountain in mist.`
`Still. Watching. Ready.`

> The party pushes forward into the mist-bound trail, boots crunching against the frostbitten road that winds like a pale artery into the dark heart of the forest.

> The Svalich Woods rise on either side—ancient, oppressive, and gnarled. Their branches reach overhead like the limbs of dying titans, forming a canopy that drinks what little light filters through the mist. The air is damp, deadened. Sounds are swallowed—your voices don't carry far, and even your steps seem muffled by the blanket of mist that clings to your cloaks and lashes at your cheeks with cold breath.

> The raven follows. Always behind you, or ahead—never seen in flight, only appearing. It perches on low-hanging limbs, black eyes glinting with unnatural focus. Its caws are few, but every one feels like punctuation.

> Hours pass. The road offers no turns, no crossroads—only a steady, creeping descent through trees that do not change. It’s as though the forest itself is locked in place, unchanging, eternal. The fog shifts in density, at times nearly parting, and at others curling around your ankles like clinging fingers.

> Then—a break in the trees. The path widens slightly, the oppressive limbs thinning just enough for the mist to spill forward like a stage curtain being drawn back.

> And there they stand. The Gates of Barovia—their iron bars twisted with age, streaked by centuries of rain and rust. Dew beads on the metal like cold sweat. The stone buttresses to either side loom high, their surfaces dark with moss and time. Vines cling to their cracked faces, as though the forest itself is trying to reclaim them.

> To either side, guardians once stood. Now, only their headless bodies remain—stoic figures carved in stone, clutching eroded swords. Their broken helms lie shattered in the weeds at their feet, eyes lost to time and lichen. In death, they seem to watch still... but without judgment. Only endurance.

> The iron gates themselves hang ajar, as if awaiting your arrival. No wind moves them, and yet, they creak softly on their hinges—as if exhaling.

> Behind you, the fog grows thicker. It pulses once—almost... possessively.

> The raven, still watching from a branch above the gate, tilts its head. It lets out a single, low caw—and then falls silent once more.
Gates of Barovia
(Arkath is proficient with both navigators tools and cartographers tools. Does the region look familiar to him)

`Nico begins looking at the architecture of a time past`
(Does Nico notice any potential traps/dangers in the immediate vicinity? Not sure if this would be a perception or investigation check?)

@AC **Nico roll an Investigation Check - Examining the Gate**

embeds.title: Nico Varn makes an Investigation check!

messages.content:
@AC **Investigation (Nico Varn): 10 – Examining the Gate**

> You scan the towering stone buttresses and rust-streaked iron gates, your eyes lingering on the broken statues and the weather-worn joints of the hinges. The architecture is undeniably ancient—possibly pre-dating known kingdom records. Its craftsmanship is formidable, meant not just to withstand time, but to intimidate.

> Despite the eerie decay and the looming dread that clings to every stone, you notice no clear mechanisms for traps. No false stones. No hidden slots or pressure plates. If there's danger here, it's not mechanical.

> But something still scratches at your instincts. The danger isn’t in how this gate was built. It’s in the fact that it’s still standing. Waiting. The silence beyond dares you to enter.

embeds.title: Arkath Grey makes a History check!

messages.content:
@Tinockerjoe **History (Arkath Grey): 20 – Searching for Clues of the Past**

> As you gaze upon the towering gate and the weathered statues, your mind turns to everything you've studied—forgotten kingdoms, collapsed empires, ruins buried beneath more ruins. But this... this is *different*.

> The style of masonry, though time-worn, bears no sigils, no markings of any known civilization. The armor on the headless guardians resembles no uniform you’ve cataloged—neither elven nor human, neither Netherese nor Oeridian. The way the stone was worked, the proportions of the gate—none of it fits. It’s as though it was made by hands that had seen the world die once already, and built again not with hope, but with *warning*.

> Barovia is not on any map you've studied. No explorer’s tale. It is a *void in your knowledge*—and that absence is *terrifying*.

> This place doesn’t exist in the world you know.

> And yet… here it stands.

`Ber stands still as stone, eyes scanning the broken statues and rust-worn gates. The mist curls around his boots like a cat with bad intentions.`
`He shifts his greatsword on his back, then glances sideways at the raven overhead.`

"Well..."` he rumbles, voice low but steady,`
"... we aren't getting any younger standing here." 

`With that, he steps forward toward the open gates, one hand brushing the hilt at his side, the other ready to part the fog.`

“Agreed. Although I must point out that in all my studies, I have never come across anything that even hints at any of this. Not the armor. Not the architecture. Not even the region around us. It is almost as if we are in a place that is otherworldly. We should tread carefully.”

`Now that there is more visibility, Arkath will try to stealthily scout around as the party heads down the path.  Not wandering far, just 10-20 feet off the path to either side of the party.`

`Korrin nods grimly at Arkath's assessment, the scholar in him deeply unsettled by the complete absence of historical precedent. His druidic training has taught him to read the stories written in stone and root, but here even nature seems rewritten by foreign rules.`

`As Ber moves toward the gates with characteristic directness and Arkath begins his careful scouting, Korrin falls into step with the group. His amber eyes track the raven's position while his other senses probe the unnatural stillness around them.`

`He keeps his voice low, meant for his companions but respectful of the oppressive silence:` "Arkath's right—this place seems to exist outside normal reality. But... I'm guessing we're committed now." `He glances at the fog thickening behind them, cutting off retreat.` "Whatever brought us here wants us to proceed."

`His hand rests lightly on his grimoire as they approach the threshold.` "Hmm, I feel we should stay alert. In sucha a place as this that doesn't follow natural law, I would wager the usual rules of survival may not apply either."

`With measured steps, he moves forward with his companions through the Gates of Barovia, crossing from the world they know into something altogether different.` ***(I would like to perform a perception check as we start to move forward)***
